text:
This Pull Request bring back Kamitani reconstruction example.

It adds the function to fetch the dataset, a bit of code from visvis to produce animated gifs and an exemple that perform a reconstruction and output it in a gif and a video.

text:
The carousel as well as the navbar behaves a bit badly on small mobile screens like the Motorola RAZR V8 for example:

![screenshot at 2013-09-12 10 47 54](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1378870/1129315/536aa230-1b88-11e3-949e-7ea523da2d1c.png)
![screenshot at 2013-09-12 10 48 05](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1378870/1129316/5868041c-1b88-11e3-8720-fb11a261efd7.png)

---

The second is just to add `doctools.js` to the themes/nilearn/static/ directory, in order to have the carousel be able to scroll pictures

This is a little fix for that behaviour
title: NiLearn Website - Tweaks for small phone screens and add doctools.js to _static

text: LGTM. Thanks! :+1: for merge.
Hold on with this one for just now
Alright - this one is ready.. Build is [here](http://jaquesgrobler.github.io/online-sklearn-build/index.html)

Hey Jaques,

Thanks for patch. Philippe and me have done few changes to the CSS. Maybe we should make a branch for the last little details. We are not aware of all the choices made for the display so we want you to take a look at it. Can we discuss that tomorrow ?
@AlexandreAbraham sure thats fine by me .. thanks

Since we're spending time on mobile devices support, it seems to me that using minified versions of the javascript files would be a good idea. It would reduce loading time, and leverage caching. Mobile devices usually have a policy of caching only very small files (http://www.yuiblog.com/blog/2010/06/28/mobile-browser-cache-limits/). Even jQuery itself is probably too big.

@jaquesgrobler can you add the minified versions of jquery.js, doctools.js, etc.? (and use them in html, instead of the current versions). You may want to keep readable files as well (but not use them in html), that would help future debugging/understanding.
Yes, let's merge this.
haha I can't merge on NiLearn - forgot :blush: One of you will have to do it
No problem, I'll take care of that. But can you add the minified js files first?

text:
Add Multi Subject Dictionary Learning.

This is an early PR. MSDL is not a full data processing pipeline (like CanICA) on purpose. The code is a bit generic: BaseGSPCA allows the developper to specify any norm / proximal operator so that it is easy to change the regularization.
title: Multi Subject Dictionary Learning

text:
Add Multi Subject Dictionary Learning.

This is an early PR. MSDL is not a full data processing pipeline (like CanICA) on purpose. The code is a bit generic: BaseGSPCA allows the developper to specify any norm / proximal operator so that it is easy to change the regularization.
title: Multi Subject Dictionary Learning

text
title: title

text:
This is an implementation of the algorithm described in 

_Jean Honorio and Dimitris Samaras "Simultaneous and Group-Sparse Multi-Task Learning of Gaussian Graphical Models", arXiv:1207.4255 (17 July 2012), http://arxiv.org/abs/1207.4255._

Given several sets of input signals, it computes several sparse precision matrices at once, using a common sparsity pattern.

The implementation itself is already fairly stable and optimized. It remains mainly some technical issues (like API, argument names, etc.). Namely:
- [x] Settle on names for functions and classes, the current ones may not be the best (group_sparse_covariance GroupSparseCovariance and GroupSparseCovarianceCV)
- [x] Clean up handling of stopping criteria (esp. the _group_sparse_covariance_costs function)
- [x] Separate in GroupSparseCovarianceCV the parameters for selection of alpha and parameters for final fit.
- [x] Automatically normalize input signals.
- [x] Clean up user messages, use the logging system of PR #84 (or similar). 
- [x] Write some documentation on the inner working of the CV version, namely the modified stopping criterion to stop optimization.
- [x] Rename the internal variable `Winv` into `W_inv`
- [x] Rename the regularization parameter `rho` to `alpha`, to match scikit-learn's convention. This implies renaming an internal variable already called `alpha`
- [x] add support for caching in GroupSparseCovariance|CV
title: [ENH] Group-sparse precision estimation, by Honorio & Samaras.
[ENH] Group-sparse precision estimation, by Honorio & Samaras.

text:
This is an implementation of the algorithm described in 

_Jean Honorio and Dimitris Samaras "Simultaneous and Group-Sparse Multi-Task Learning of Gaussian Graphical Models", arXiv:1207.4255 (17 July 2012), http://arxiv.org/abs/1207.4255._

Given several sets of input signals, it computes several sparse precision matrices at once, using a common sparsity pattern.

The implementation itself is already fairly stable and optimized. It remains mainly some technical issues (like API, argument names, etc.). Namely:
- [x] Settle on names for functions and classes, the current ones may not be the best (group_sparse_covariance GroupSparseCovariance and GroupSparseCovarianceCV)
- [x] Clean up handling of stopping criteria (esp. the _group_sparse_covariance_costs function)
- [x] Separate in GroupSparseCovarianceCV the parameters for selection of alpha and parameters for final fit.
- [x] Automatically normalize input signals.
- [x] Clean up user messages, use the logging system of PR #84 (or similar). 
- [x] Write some documentation on the inner working of the CV version, namely the modified stopping criterion to stop optimization.
- [x] Rename the internal variable `Winv` into `W_inv`
- [x] Rename the regularization parameter `rho` to `alpha`, to match scikit-learn's convention. This implies renaming an internal variable already called `alpha`
- [x] add support for caching in GroupSparseCovariance|CV
title: [ENH] Group-sparse precision estimation, by Honorio & Samaras.

title: Pull request merge from pgervais/nilearn:honorio_samaras to nilearn/nilearn:master

text: Travis failed... with what looks as a somewhat trivial bug.

>    I know that looking at the example is the simplest thing to do. And I also
>    know that there is many things to do, including those that you just
>    pointed out. What I really need is feedback on the core of the
>    algorithm...

I need to be able to run it to inspect it.
I just noticed that the group_sparse_covariance tests are very long running. We should work on making them faster.

> Wait. I already have the answer: compare the two algorithms.

Yup
I didn't check the tests before creating the PR. I'll fix that soon.

I know that looking at the example is the simplest thing to do. And I also know that there is many things to do, including those that you just pointed out. What I really need is feedback on the core of the algorithm...
Tnx for the nice work, and sorry for bothering you with details. This PR should obviously get in.

I'm now starting to clean up the examples that show off GroupSparseCovarianceCV. There are two files that do almost the same thing: `plot_adhd_covariance.py` and `plot_adhd_covariance2.py`. The first loads data for one subject, and compute a CV'd graph lasso. The second loads data for several subjects and compute a CV'd group-sparse covariance. There are in practice only one thing that differs between them: the optimization algorithm. The code is mostly copy-pasted.

I think keeping only the group-sparse one is enough. What do you think?
Wait. I already have the answer: compare the two algorithms.

In the last commits, I added two pages of documentation. One is about functional connectivity analysis with nilearn (in user's guide, under "unsupervised learning"), the other is a technical description of the implementation of the group-sparse covariance algorithm. The latter is accessible via a link at the very bottom of the former. This link is rather hard to find, it has been done on purpose: the technical page is for developers or machine-learning guys.
Besides a couple of typos, everything looks file. Thanks for the documentation.
This file need a better name and a better title.

title: (None, '', u'doc/developers/group_sparse_covariance.rst')

text: First steps on Honorio-Samaras algorithm

Test signals generator

Code for main algorithm has been completed, but not tested (it has not
been run at all).

Corrected some bugs in Newton-Raphson step

Adapted the formula to enforce a positive solution.
The formula used for the second derivative contained an error (bad
sign).

Algorithm works on test case.

In the current state, the algorithm converges for different test cases.

The function contains **much** code for testing and asserting, that slows
down things a lot.

Added a debugging flag

Removed some test code.

Working example of honorio-samaras algorithm

This example is really rough, and there is debugging code everywhere.
But this state works.
Code cleanup
Optimized Newton-Raphson step.
Reduced memory consumption in _detrend

Reduced memory usage in _detrend, again

This memory usage reduction applies to all cases, instead of the previous
commit which improved a corner case.

Created _mean_of_squares

This function will replace a similar computation in high_variance_confounds()
which uses much more memory (execution time is similar, if not smaller).
Lower memory usage for high_variance_confound

Improved performance of H-S algorithm implementation

Replaced a loop by a numpy operation. Around 15% speedup on
plot_adhd_covariance2.py with 40 subjects.
Solved remaining problems after merging.

Renamed honorio_samaras function

New name: group_spare_covariance()
Updated docstring.

Added a test for group_sparse_covariance

Big code cleanup

Another optimization in group_sparse_covariance

The computation of an matrix inverse has been replaced by a computation
based on Sherman-Woodbury-Morrison formula. This improves the asymptotic
running time for a large number of variables.

group_sparse_covariance takes signals as input

The group_sparse_covariance() signature has been changed, to be
consistent with that of analogous functions in scikit-learn.

Added tests for group_sparse_covariance, adapted every example.

Created GroupSparseCovariance

Improved user messages in group_sparse_covariance
Moved LogMixin out of nifti_region.py.

Added duality gap computation

The return_costs keyword of group_sparse_covariance nows returns the
duality gap in addition to the primal problem cost.

Small optimization of cost computation

duality gap and objective in group_sparse_covariance are now computed
inside a single function. This is faster than the previous two-function
implementation.

Added duality gap and rho max computations

Duality gap is computed with return_costs=True.

rho max is the value of the regularization parameter above which the
resulting matrix is completely sparse (will be useful for cross-validated
estimator)
First implementation of GroupSparseCovarianceCV
Parallel computation in GroupSparseCovarianceCV

Better duality gap computation

The computation now seems to always give positive duality gap.

Added tolerance-based stop criterion

The duality gap is compared to a tolerance value. Computation is
stopped if gap is smaller than tolerance.

Added tests for GroupSparseCovariance(CV)

Corrected some bugs thanks to the tests.

Added a warning in group_sparse_covariance

A warning is issued when tolerance is not reached with the prescribed
number of iterations.
Tiny optimization: saved some memory allocation.
Fixed a spurious warning in a test

Reorganized code

Split group_sparse_covariance in two functions: one that takes signals
as input (for users) and one that takes empirical covariances (for
internal usage). This prepares for some more optimization of the
cross-validation function.

Improved GroupSparseCovarianceCV (faster)

Used restart value to (slightly) reduce convergence time.

Updated documentation
Added functions to generate test signals.

Duality gap is not inf anymore

In some cases where the empirical covariance matrices were singular,
the duality gap as computed previously could take infinite values. This
has been fixed by computing another feasible dual point in such cases.
The computed value is not a tight bound, but it is believed to be only
useful far from the optimum.

Added objective value in user messages during computation.
Corrected a bug in signals generation
Intermediate possibly buggy state

Updated generate_sparse_precision_matrix

Added an option to get an corresponding covariance matrix with
only ones on the diagonal.

Optimized Newton-Raphson step.

Dropped dependence on scipy for Newton-Raphson.
Code cleanup
Time is returned along with costs

Changed stopping criterion

Iterations are now stopped when all coefficients in the estimated
precision matrix change less than the tolerance between two
iterations.
This gives kind of a guaranteed number of decimals in the estimated
precision matrices.
Minor bug fix.

Probing of group_sparse_covariance

Added keyword "probe_function" to group_sparse_covariance. This is a
way to provide a function that is called after each iteration. See
aspect-oriented programming.

Updated the standard message displayed for each iteration, to show the
max norm of the difference between two estimation of the precision
matrices.

Remove "return_costs" keyword

This keyword is useless because the same feature can be obtained using
a probe.

Code cleanup

Almost every "dtype" keyword argument has been removed.

Optimized group_sparse_covariance()

Gained 20% execution time on a particular case (mainly in the Newton-
Raphson part)

One more small optimization in GSC.

GSC: group_sparse_covariance

Fixed an import bug.

Added some documentation to group_sparse_covariance()
Arguments passed to probe function are correct now

Added early stopping to GroupSparseCovarianceCV

Early stopping also to run cross-validation code faster, by stopping
iteration before reaching convergence according to maximum norm.

group_sparse_score output has been modified: the first value is now
the log-likelihood on test set (instead of the opposite of it: the
sign was changed).

Updated docstrings.
Code cleanup

Started renaming "rho" to "alpha"

Got rid of conflicting usage of the "alpha" name.

Code refactoring

- Renamings: task->subject, rho->alpha.
- Fixed a lot of docstrings
- Removed some constructs not compatible with Python 3 (xrange)
- Refactored plot_adhd_covariance2 a lot. Now shorter and much clearer.
- Replaced numpy.linalg.inv by scipy.linalg.inv

Renamed internal variable

Winv -> W_inv

Code cleanup (doc, api)

group_sparse_score() renamed to group_sparse_scores() (added an S)

Code simplification and cleanup

Replace some custom code by sklearn.utils.gen_even_slices

Got rid of spurious warning in tests

Docstring and comments fixes.
generate_group_sparse_gaussian_graphs() in testing

Improved numerical stability

Added two lines to force symmetric at the end of _update_submatrix.

Some cleanup.

Merge branch 'master' into honorio_samaras

Conflicts:
	nilearn/input_data/nifti_region.py
	nilearn/tests/__init__.py
group_sparse_covariance uses logger.log()
Remove LogMixin class.
Code cleanup
Code cleanup
Small docstring fixes

Added a technical documentation page

The documentation is about the group sparse covariance algorithm.
No link to it has been added in index.rst yet.
Merged graph lasso and group-sparse examples

"standardize" keyword for empirical_covariances

Standardizing time series is required for numerical stability of group-
sparse covariance optimization. This is technically useful for the
cross-validated version.

[DOC] group-sparse covariance

Added information of parallelism, grid search and warm restart.

Clean up duality gap computation

Move duality gap computation into group_sparse_scores().

Group-sparse covariance estimation is now always performed in
double precision.

Separated convergence parameters in CV

In GroupSparseCovarianceCV, tolerance and maximum iteration number can
have different values for the alpha selection phase, and the final
optimization. Two keywords have been added: tol_cv and max_iter_cv.
Example comparing sparse precision estimation

Removed "assume_centered" keyword in g.s.c.

The "assume_centered" keyword has been removed from every function
related to group-sparse covariance (useless).

[DOC] fixed paragraph on data extraction

plot_adhd_covariance.py example had changed a lot, the rst file was
referencing lines that didn't exist anymore.
[BUG] compatibility with sklearn 0.10-0.14

[DOC] functional connectivity page

And a page on the technical aspects of the group-sparse covariance
implementation.

Also fixed some bugs.

Merge branch 'master' into honorio_samaras

Conflicts:
	doc/index.rst

[TST] Fix failing test

A test is failing on Travis (np.diff(objective) <= 0 in
test_group_sparse_covariance.py:51), that does not occur of the
developer's machine. np.diff(objective) may be hitting the numerical
noise floor (1e-14 or so). Some values may then be slightly positive.
This is most probably due to a different numerical library which leads to
a slightly different result.

The fix consists in decreasing the number of iterations so that optimization
stops before hitting the noise floor.
[DOC] fixed some typos
gives
